notes.text:
An update for the mod_auth_openidc:2.3 module is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The mod_auth_openidc is an OpenID Connect authentication module for Apache HTTP Server. It enables an Apache HTTP Server to operate as an OpenID Connect Relying Party and/or OAuth 2.0 Resource Server. 

Security Fix(es):

* cjose: AES GCM decryption uses the Tag length from the actual Authentication Tag provided in the JWE (CVE-2023-37464)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

cwe.name: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm

notes.text: A vulnerability was found in cjose. The cjose is a C library implementing the Javascript Object Signing and Encryption (JOSE). The AES GCM decryption routine incorrectly uses the tag length from the actual Authentication Tag provided in the  JSON Web Encryption (JWE). A fixed length of 16 octets must be applied. This flaw allows an attacker to provide a truncated Authentication Tag and modify the JWE.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: cjose: AES GCM decryption uses the Tag length from the actual Authentication Tag provided in the JWE
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
Users unable to upgrade should avoid using AES GCM encryption and replace it with another encryption algorithm, such as AES CBC.

vulnerabilities.title: cjose: AES GCM decryption uses the Tag length from the actual Authentication Tag provided in the JWE
